TextEquiv.Unicode: stand by the word of God, least perad
venture the same Apostle condemne
us who saith: whoso hath this worlds
good and seeth his brother have need,
and shutteth up his compassion from
him, how dwelleth the love of God in
him
And nowe let us also declare the
fourth and last maner howe we ought
to stand our neighbour in steede, & how
to do him good in shewing our dutifull
love and civill humanitie. That hath
the Lorde alreadie very finely set out,
in the very same parable wherein hee
taught us who is our neighbour. For
he hath briefly, and yet verie evidently
touched all the pointes of the love that
we owe to our neighbour. First the
Samaritane at the sight of the woun
ded man, was mooved with pitie.
There is therefore required of us a
mercifull motion of pitie, so to regard
other mennes calamities, as though
they were our owne: it is looked for
at our handes, that wee should be as
forrowfull minded for an other mans
trouble , as he that feeleth the mise
rie, according to that saying of the
Apostle. Be mindfull of them that are
in bondes, as bounde with them, and
of them which suffer adversitie, as
though yee your selves also being in
the bodie suffered adversitle. Se con
darilie, the Samaritane passeth not
by, but commeth unto him, he doth not
with forrowfull words wish health to
the wounded, and so letting him lie,
depart to dispatch his owne affaires:
For James the Apostle saieth: If a
brother or sister bee naked and desti
tute of daily foode, aud one of you
say unto them, depart in peace, be ye
warmed and silled: and yet notwith
standing give them not those thinges
that are needefull to the bodie, what
shall it pro

stand by the word of God, least perad venture the same Apostle condemne us who saith: whoso hath this worlds good and seeth his brother have need, and shutteth up his compassion from him, how dwelleth the love of God in him And nowe let us also declare the fourth and last maner howe we ought to stand our neighbour in steede, & how to do him good in shewing our dutifull love and civill humanitie. That hath the Lorde alreadie very finely set out, in the very same parable wherein hee taught us who is our neighbour. For he hath briefly, and yet verie evidently touched all the pointes of the love that we owe to our neighbour. First the Samaritane at the sight of the woun ded man, was mooved with pitie. There is therefore required of us a mercifull motion of pitie, so to regard other mennes calamities, as though they were our owne: it is looked for at our handes, that wee should be as forrowfull minded for an other mans trouble , as he that feeleth the mise rie, according to that saying of the Apostle. Be mindfull of them that are in bondes, as bounde with them, and of them which suffer adversitie, as though yee your selves also being in the bodie suffered adversitle. Se con darilie, the Samaritane passeth not by, but commeth unto him, he doth not with forrowfull words wish health to the wounded, and so letting him lie, depart to dispatch his owne affaires: For James the Apostle saieth: If a brother or sister bee naked and desti tute of daily foode, aud one of you say unto them, depart in peace, be ye warmed and silled: and yet notwith standing give them not those thinges that are needefull to the bodie, what shall it pro
therefore commeth unto him, setteth
too his hande , and sheweth the skill
that he hath (which was not much y
wis) to heale the seely mangled man.
He doth not loath and turne his face
from the illfavoured colour, bloudie
matter, corrupted filth and stench
of his woundes, he bindeth them by
him elfe, not letting them alone for
an other to doe. Hee maketh not his
excuse, that he is no Phisician: but
doth what hee can in that necessitie,
using such medicine as for the time
present he had in a readinesse, till more
conveviently hee might come by bet
ter. Vine and Gyle hee had taken
with him when he beganne his iour
ney, which in that necessitie hee doeth
use, and that not verie inconvenient
ly, because wine purgeth woundes
and oyle doeth make them supple.
Moreover, whatsoever he hath, that
doeth he imploy to the seely mans be
hoofe, and to doe him ease doeth even
disease him selfe. For hee alighteth
from the backe of the beast whereon
hee rode, and maketh him to serue the
maimed mannes necessitie. He also
with his owne handes lifteth up from
the grounde the man that was too
weake to stande, and setteth him on
the beast. And lastly, hee himselfe be
commeth his guide to leade the way,
not suffring anie other to take charege
over him. For when as he could not
readily bring him to his owne house,
yet did he convey him into a common
Inne. There againe he spareth not
for any cost or paines taking. For he
himselfe taketh charege of the misera
ble man, because in common Innes
ficke folkes, for the most part, are flen
derly looked unto. But when his ear
nest businesse calleth on to make haste
in his iourney, hee taketh out so much
money as he doth thinke to be suffici

therefore commeth unto him, setteth too his hande , and sheweth the skill that he hath (which was not much y wis) to heale the seely mangled man. He doth not loath and turne his face from the illfavoured colour, bloudie matter, corrupted filth and stench of his woundes, he bindeth them by him elfe, not letting them alone for an other to doe. Hee maketh not his excuse, that he is no Phisician: but doth what hee can in that necessitie, using such medicine as for the time present he had in a readinesse, till more conveviently hee might come by bet ter. Vine and Gyle hee had taken with him when he beganne his iour ney, which in that necessitie hee doeth use, and that not verie inconvenient ly, because wine purgeth woundes and oyle doeth make them supple. Moreover, whatsoever he hath, that doeth he imploy to the seely mans be hoofe, and to doe him ease doeth even disease him selfe. For hee alighteth from the backe of the beast whereon hee rode, and maketh him to serue the maimed mannes necessitie. He also with his owne handes lifteth up from the grounde the man that was too weake to stande, and setteth him on the beast. And lastly, hee himselfe be commeth his guide to leade the way, not suffring anie other to take charege over him. For when as he could not readily bring him to his owne house, yet did he convey him into a common Inne. There againe he spareth not for any cost or paines taking. For he himselfe taketh charege of the misera ble man, because in common Innes ficke folkes, for the most part, are flen derly looked unto. But when his ear nest businesse calleth on to make haste in his iourney, hee taketh out so much money as he doth thinke to be suffici
